# Google Chrome
Google Chrome is a freeware [[web-browsers|web browser]] developed by Google. It was first released in 2008, for Microsoft Windows, and was later ported to Linux, macOS, iOS and Android. Google Chrome is also the main component of Chrome OS, where it serves as a platform for running web apps.

Google releases the majority of Chrome's source code as the Chromium [[open-source|open-source project]]. A notable component that is not open-source is the built-in Adobe Flash Player (that Chrome has disabled by default since September 2016). Chrome used the WebKit layout engine until version 27. As of version 28, all Chrome ports except the iOS port use Blink, a fork of the WebKit engine.

As of February 2017, StatCounter estimates that Google Chrome has a 62% worldwide usage share of web browsers as a desktop browser. It also has 52% market share across all platforms combined, because it is also the most popular browser for smartphones. Its success has led to Google expanding the "Chrome" brand name on various other products such as Chromecast, Chromebook, Chromebit, Chromebox and Chromebase.

[Website](https://google.com/chrome/browser/desktop/)

Wiki Formatting
=======
### ZeroWiki supports basic markdown tags, below is a collection of helpful tags to help visitors create articles with style.

---

Paragraphs are separated
by a blank line.

Two spaces at the end of a line leave a  
line break.

---

Horizontal Lines  like this can be done with \***, \--- and \___

---

An [external link](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D).  
A [clearnet link](https://zeronet.io).

        An [external link](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1HeLLo4uzjaLetFx6NH3PMwFP3qbRbTf3D).  
        A [clearnet link](https://zeronet.io).

An internal link like [[ZeroWiki:Sandbox]].  

        An internal link like ​[​[ZeroWiki:Sandbox]].
​
---

This is [an example] [id] reference-[style] link. 
[id]: http://example1.com/  "Optional Title1 Here"
[style]: http://example2.com/  "Optional Title2 Here"

        This is [an example] [id] reference-[style] link. 
        [id]: http://example1.com/  "Optional Title1 Here" 
        [style]: http://example2.com/  "Optional Title2 Here" 
​

---

![Image AltText](img/zerowiki.jpg "Optional title")  

        ![Image AltText](img/zerowiki.jpg "Optional title")
​

---

This Is A Heading
===  
        This Is A Heading
        ===

This Is A Sub-heading
----  
       This Is A Sub-heading
       ----
 
# This Is H1  
        # This Is H1  
 ## This Is H2  
        ## This Is H2  
### This Is H3  
        ### This Is H3  
#### This Is H4  
        #### This Is H4  
​

---

Text attributes:  

| Markdown           | Normal          |  
| ------------- |:-------------:|  
|.................... |......................|  
| _italic_  | \_Italic_  |  
|.................... |......................| 
| **bold**  | \*\*Bold**  |  
|.................... |......................|  
| `monospace` | \`Monospace` |  
|.................... |......................|  
​

---

   ### How to make a list:  
   notice the two spaces before *pears* and *oranges*. They will make it a sub-list.  

```
Numbered list:  

  1. apples
  2. oranges
    * pears  
  3. banana
```
```
 Bullet list:

  * apples 
    1. oranges
  * pears
  * banana
```

Numbered list:  
1. apples
2. oranges
  * pears  
3. banana

Bullet list:  
  * apples     
    1. oranges
  * banana                   
  * pears                       
​
---
### To make a code snippet:  

| Markdown           | Normal          |  
| ---------------------------- |:----------------------------:|  
|.................................................. |....................................................|  
| ``` The code you want to see ```  |     \`\`\` The code you want to see \`\`\`   
​

---
### Making a table:  
As an escape char you can use "\" before the char you want to escape. This will make it read as a normal character and not hold any special meaning. Good if you want to write a \* for instance.

```
| Markdown           | Normal             |  
| ------------------ |:------------------:|  
|................... |....................|  
|* markymark *       | ​nonormal           |  
```  
| Markdown           | Normal                    |  
| ----------------------- |:-----------------------:|  
|....................... |.........................|  
| ** markymark **         | ​nonormal               |  
​

---
### Escaping a markdown character:  
As an escape char you can use "\" before the char you want to escape. This will make it read as a normal character and not hold any special meaning. Good if you want to write a \* for instance.

| Markdown           | Normal          
| ------------- |:-------------:|  
|.............................. |................................|  
| \*literal asterisks\*  | ​\\\* literal asterisks​\​*  |  
​

---
Further reading can be done at [GitHub's Markdown-Cheatsheet](https://github.com/adam-p/markdown-here/wiki/Markdown-Cheatsheet)
​

# Welcome to ZeroNet

[[ZeroWiki]] is a wiki platform for [[ZeroNet]], the distributed web network based on [[Bittorrent]], [[Bitcoin]] and [[Tor]]. 

[[ZeroWiki]] is public, [[cloning|clonable]]. Wikis can be used for taking notes, storing snippets, sharing knowledge by creating [[FAQ]]s and documentations, keeping track of your goals, or as a simple to-do lists. See the [[help|help page]] for a more in-depth view of how it works.

## Useful pages

- [[zeronet|What is ZeroNet ?]]
- [[zite|What is a "zite"?]]
- [[ZeroWiki:Format|ZeroWiki writing format]]
- [[List of Zites]]
- [[Dev ideas|Development ideas]]
- [[proxies|List of proxies, allowing you to view ZeroNet from clearnet]]
- [[zerowikisandbox|Sandbox, you can play with it before editing other pages]]

*Please note that [[ZeroWiki]] is still beta software, it may have bugs and lack some features
[[ZeroWiki:Issues|Propose features and report bugs here]].*

Tor
===

What is Tor?
---
Tor is a service that helps you to protect your anonymity while using the Internet. Tor is comprised of two parts: software you can download that allows you to use the Internet anonymously, and the volunteer network of computers that makes it possible for that software to work.

Who created the Tor network?
---
The core principle of Tor, "onion routing", was developed in the mid-1990s by United States Naval Research Laboratory employees, mathematician Paul Syverson and computer scientists Michael Reed and David Goldschlag, with the purpose of protecting U.S. intelligence communications online.

Nowadays the software is maintained by the [Tor Project](https://torproject.org) and has stemmed into several child projects based on it, such as the TorBrowser (for desktop systems) , Orbot (for Android systems) and others.

Is it illegal to use the Tor Browser?
---
Using Tor to browse the Internet is not illegal. 
Hiding your IP address and browsing history is not illegal in and of itself. 

However, don't forget that the concept of legality varies according to the laws of a given place. The above is true for the United States, and probably for most of Europe and South America as well, but might be different for your country.

How do you connect to the Web through the Tor network?
---
The simplest way is using the Tor Browser Bundle which contains all the required tools. To install it, go to [www.torproject.org](https://www.torproject.org) and download the appropriate file for your operating system. (Check the PGP signature of the downloaded file to verify integrity). Run the downloaded file, choose an extraction location, then open the folder and click Start Tor Browser.  Depending on where you are, you may need use bridges such as obfs4 or meek-google.

Using Tor to browse the Internet is not illegal.

# Project Maelstrom

[Official website](http://blog.bittorrent.com/tag/maelstrom/)
[torrent-web-tools Github](https://github.com/bittorrent/torrent-web-tools)

**Project Maelstrom** is a distributed internet browser by [[Bittorrent Inc.]]. The project was launched as alpha on December 10, 2014 and subsequently as beta on April 10, 2015. It allowed for the distribution of dynamic sites in a decentralized manner, and examples of webapps such as a task list and 3D rendering were provided.

The project is now considered defunct due to the lack of active development by Bittorrent (last blog post October 29, 2015), but the project downloads are still available at the website. It is available for Windows.

# World Wide Web

An information system on the [[Internet]] that allows documents to be connected to other documents by hypertext links, enabling the user to search for information by moving from one document to another.

# World Wide Web

An [[information]] system on the [[Internet]] that allows documents to be connected to other documents by hypertext links, enabling the user to search for information by moving from one document to another.

# World Wide Web

An information [[system]] on the [[Internet]] that allows documents to be connected to other documents by hypertext links, enabling the user to search for information by moving from one document to another.

# World Wide Web

An information system on the [[Internet]] that allows documents to be connected to other documents by hypertext links, enabling the user to search for information by moving from one document to another.

# Decentralized

A decentralized network is a network where there is no centralized point of access (unlike traditional networks with clients and servers) and therefore no single point of failure. In a decentralized network, files are distributed by multiple users, rather than solely the owner of those files.

# Decentralized

A decentralized [[network]] is a network where there is no centralized point of access (unlike traditional networks with clients and servers) and therefore no single point of failure. In a decentralized network, files are distributed by multiple users, rather than solely the owner of those files.

# ZeroNet

**ZeroNet** is a [[decentralized]] network of [[peer-to-peer]] users. It is built in [[Python]] and fully [[open source]]. Sites have specific addresses which can be accessed through a browser when using its client. ZeroNet is not [[anonymous]] by default, but users can hide their IP address by using the built in [[Tor]]-functionality. ZeroNet uses [[Bitcoin]] [[cryptography]] and the [[BitTorrent]] network.

Users can publish static or dynamic websites into ZeroNet and visitors automatically serve the visited website from their computer, with the option to stop serving the website at any time by either pausing or deleting it. Sites will remain online even if it is being served by only one [[peer-to-peer|peer]].

When changes are published by the site owner, connected [[nodes]] serving that site (previous visitors) will receive the updates done to the site's content.

ZeroNet comes with a built-in [[SQL]] [[database]]. This makes content-heavy site development easy. The [[database]] is also synced with hosting [[nodes]].

The existence of [[peer-to-peer]] online [[website]]s had been hypothesized for some time, with [[The Pirate Bay]] suggesting they would build such network, as well as [[BitTorrent Inc.]] which created the closed source [[Project Maelstrom]]. One other similar project is [[MaidSafe]], though it has not yet seen widespread use, and has been said to focus more on file storage.
